themes.label: Decrees
themes.rationale: The inscription begins with the standard formula for a public decree, indicating a formal decision made by the people of Miletus.
themes.quote: δοξε τ ι δ μωι γν μη συν δρων

themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The text details various honors granted to Antiochus, including a bronze statue on horseback, front-row seating at festivals, and tax exemptions.
themes.quote: παιν σαι μ ν [ ντ οχον τ]ς περ τ ν θε ν ε σεβε ας κα τ ς [πρ ς το ς λλην]ας ε νο ας

themes.label: Building Commemoration
themes.rationale: The inscription records the promise and planning for the construction of a stoa (colonnade) at the sanctuary of Didyma by Antiochus.
themes.quote: στο ν ο κοδο[μ σειν σταδια αν τ ι θε] ι κατ π λιν

themes.label: Accounts and Financial Records
themes.rationale: The decree includes instructions for treasurers regarding the management of revenues and the funding for the honors and construction.
themes.quote: το ς δ ταμ α[ς πωλε ν κ]α το ς [ ε] καθισταμ νους πρυτ νης [παρα]δ χεσθαι [τ ν] γινομ νην [ π] α τ ς πρ σ[οδον]

themes.label: Votive Dedications
themes.rationale: The construction of the stoa is framed as a religious offering to the god at Didyma, reflecting the piety of the royal family.
themes.quote: περ τ ερ ν [τ]ν διδ μοις καλ ς χειν

rationale: This inscription is a significant Hellenistic decree from Miletus, dated to approximately 300/299 BC. It records the honors bestowed upon Antiochus (the future Antiochus I Soter), son of Seleucus I Nicator, in recognition of his promise to build a large stoa at the sanctuary of Apollo in Didyma. The text is a classic example of the relationship between Hellenistic monarchs and Greek cities, involving reciprocal benefaction (euergetism) and religious piety. It mentions specific civic offices like treasurers (tamiai) and prytaneis, and religious festivals like the Dionysia and Didymeia.
